description: From Middle English pork, porc, via Anglo-Norman, from Old French porc (“swine, hog, pig; pork”), from Latin porcus (“domestic hog, pig”).
Cognate with Old English fearh (“piglet”). Doublet of farrow.
Used in English since the 14th century, and as a term of abuse since the 17th century.

US politics sense is related to pork barrel.
The verb is from the Black American form of poke.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The meat of a pig; swineflesh.
examples: Synonyms: pigmeat, swineflesh, the other white meat
The cafeteria serves pork on Tuesdays.

entries.meaning: (US politics, slang, derogatory) Funding proposed or requested by a member of Congress for special interests or their constituency as opposed to the good of the country as a whole.
(MLE, slang, collective) law enforcement, those who side with criminal prosecution
examples: Synonyms: bacon, pigs, swine; see also Thesaurus:police
Meronym: porky (“one member of law enforcement, policeman”)

entries.meaning: (slang) A shag; a fuck; an act of coitus.

verbs.description: pork (third-person singular simple present porks, present participle porking, simple past and past participle porked)

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang, vulgar, usually of a male) To have sex with (someone).
